abstract: The parent company of MTV and Comedy Central is seeking $1 billion in damages for copyright infringement.
snippet: The parent company of MTV and Comedy Central is seeking $1 billion in damages for copyright infringement.
lead_paragraph: Viacom, the parent company of MTV and Comedy Central, sued Google and YouTube in federal court today, citing “massive intentional copyright infringement.”

headline.main: Viacom Sues Google Over YouTube Video Clips

abstract: Accusing Google and its YouTube site of “massive copyright infringement,” Viacom said it was seeking more than $1 billion in damages.
snippet: Accusing Google and its YouTube site of “massive copyright infringement,” Viacom said it was seeking more than $1 billion in damages.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 — Since it bought YouTube last October, Google has been chasing deals that would give it the right to put mainstream video programming on the site. Just a few weeks ago, Google’s chief executive, Eric E. Schmidt, seemed confident that this courtship of old-line media companies would prove fruitful.

headline.main: WhoseTube? Viacom Sues Google Over Video Clips

byline.original: By Miguel Helft and Geraldine Fabrikant

abstract: Google said it would start to make search logs anonymous after 18 to 24 months. Under current practices, the company keeps the logs indefinitely.
snippet: Google said it would start to make search logs anonymous after 18 to 24 months. Under current practices, the company keeps the logs indefinitely.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, March 14 — Web search companies collect records of the searches people conduct, a fact that has long sparked fears among privacy advocates and some Internet users that this valuable personal data could be misused.

headline.main: Google Changes Policy on Search Records

abstract: Ever since Google coughed up that $1.65 billion for YouTube, critics of the online video site have been predicting a landslide of copyright lawsuits. While that landslide has yet to occur, the first boulder has fallen. Viacom, the parent company of MTV, Nickelodeon and Comedy Central, filed a wide-ranging lawsuit against Google on Tuesday, accusing it of “massive copyright infringement.” Viacom said it was seeking more than $1 billion in damages and an injunction prohibiting Google and YouTube from committing further infringement.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Google coughed up that $1.65 billion for YouTube, critics of the online video site have been predicting a landslide of copyright lawsuits. While that landslide has yet to occur, the first boulder has fallen. Viacom, the parent company of MTV, Nickelodeon and Comedy Central, filed a wide-ranging lawsuit against Google on Tuesday, accusing it of “massive copyright infringement.” Viacom said it was seeking more than $1 billion in damages and an injunction prohibiting Google and YouTube from committing further infringement.

abstract: For months, pundits have been kicking around the (wildly speculative) idea of Microsoft buying Yahoo to take on Google, the giant of the Web search world. John Battelle, the editor of SearchBlog, a blog on search technology, was among them. But now Mr. Battelle, who also founded the online ad network Federated Media Publishing, thinks he has a better idea, though one he admits might sound “crazy”: a joint venture between the two companies to create a “search monetization” business.
lead_paragraph: For months, pundits have been kicking around the (wildly speculative) idea of Microsoft buying Yahoo to take on Google, the giant of the Web search world. John Battelle, the editor of SearchBlog, a blog on search technology, was among them. But now Mr. Battelle, who also founded the online ad network Federated Media Publishing, thinks he has a better idea, though one he admits might sound “crazy”: a joint venture between the two companies to create a “search monetization” business.

headline.main: Yet More Musings on a Microsoft-Yahoo Deal

abstract: Troubles in the mortgage market have put a spotlight on the arcane world of structured finance and the alphabet soup that includes CDO’s and CMBS’s. These woes may also be creating additional opportunities for Wall Street workers who know about such complex things, according to MarketWatch’s David Weidner, who reports that “bankers and traders who have experience structuring collateralized debt obligations, or CDOs, are in high demand to feed departments handling securities backed by mortgages, assets, corporate debt and other loans.”
lead_paragraph: Troubles in the mortgage market have put a spotlight on the arcane world of structured finance and the alphabet soup that includes CDO’s and CMBS’s. These woes may also be creating additional opportunities for Wall Street workers who know about such complex things, according to MarketWatch’s David Weidner, who reports that “bankers and traders who have experience structuring collateralized debt obligations, or CDOs, are in high demand to feed departments handling securities backed by mortgages, assets, corporate debt and other loans.”

headline.main: Fast Times for Wall Street’s Debt Whizzes
